title: Day 14 - Set Up a Way to Get Paid
mainPromise: You will set up a simple payment method, create a payment link or invoice template, and test the full paid-to-intake flow.

teachings.title: Payment is part of trust
teachings.content:
Getting paid is not just money. It is credibility. A clean payment flow signals that you are organized and that the buyer will not be stuck in awkward back-and-forth.

Your payment method should match your service type: one-time fixed package, digital delivery, clear scope. You want a checkout that can include the offer description and reduce mismatch.

A payment setup also protects you. It can enforce scope, collect the buyer's email, and trigger intake.
teachings.soWhat: If payment is unclear, interested buyers hesitate and you lose momentum.

teachings.title: Checkout copy prevents bad customers
teachings.content:
Checkout is not a place for marketing paragraphs. It is a place for clarity. Your best defense against bad-fit customers is to restate scope, timeline, and what is required from them.

A small online service benefits from a simple what you get list and a scope warning line. This reduces refund pressure and reduces scope creep.

You also need basic policies: revision and refund rules that match what you wrote earlier.
teachings.soWhat: If checkout copy is vague, you will attract buyers who expect something else.

teachings.title: Test the flow like a customer
teachings.content:
A payment setup is not real until you test it end-to-end. Many small issues appear only when you act like a buyer: missing confirmation, unclear next step, wrong link, or confusing instructions.

Testing is not only technical. It is also emotional. The buyer should feel guided: pay, confirm, intake, delivery timeline.

Today you will run a test transaction flow without needing a real customer.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not test now, your first real buyer becomes your tester, and that damages trust.

doBlocks.title: Choose your payment method
steps: Pick one primary payment method and one backup.
Define what the buyer sees at checkout.
Write the required payment fields you need to capture.

items.label: Chose a primary and backup payment method
items.evidencePrompt: Write two payment methods labeled Primary and Backup.

items.label: Wrote the checkout description draft
items.evidencePrompt: Paste 80 to 120 words describing the offer at checkout.

items.label: Listed the buyer information fields you must capture
items.evidencePrompt: List required fields you must capture at payment or intake.

items.label: Wrote one sentence on how payment connects to intake
items.evidencePrompt: Write one sentence describing the payment-to-intake connection.

doBlocks.example: Primary: Payment link checkout. Backup: Invoice with card or bank transfer. Checkout description: Fixed scope, 48-hour delivery after intake, one revision, digital handoff. Payment to intake: After payment, buyer receives intake link automatically.

doBlocks.title: Create the pay page content
steps: Write the checkout headline and one-sentence promise.
Write a 5-bullet what you get list and a 5-bullet what you provide list.
Add revision and refund policy lines.

items.label: Wrote checkout headline and one-sentence promise
items.evidencePrompt: Paste the headline and one-sentence promise.

items.label: Wrote a 5-bullet what-you-get list
items.evidencePrompt: List 5 bullets describing what the buyer gets.

items.label: Wrote a 5-bullet what-you-provide list
items.evidencePrompt: List 5 bullets describing what the buyer must provide.

items.label: Added revision and refund lines
items.evidencePrompt: Paste 4 to 8 lines of revision and refund policy text.

doBlocks.example: Promise: In 48 hours, you get a simple workflow that cuts weekly admin time and reduces friction. Policy: One revision within 7 days. Refund only if delivery is not provided as described.

doBlocks.title: Run an end-to-end test
steps: Simulate the buyer path: open checkout, read copy, proceed to payment.
Confirm what happens after payment: confirmation page, email, intake link.
Document fixes and update your assets.

items.label: Completed a simulated buyer walkthrough and wrote friction notes
items.evidencePrompt: List 5 friction notes found during your buyer walkthrough.

items.label: Confirmed confirmation message content and saved it
items.evidencePrompt: Paste the confirmation content or describe it precisely.

items.label: Confirmed intake link delivery and saved the link location
items.evidencePrompt: Provide the intake link or note exactly where the link appears after payment.

items.label: Created a fix list with priorities
items.evidencePrompt: List fixes labeled High, Medium, or Low priority.

doBlocks.example: Friction note: Policy text is too long, move scope warning higher. Fix list: High: add intake link to confirmation email, Medium: shorten bullets, Low: add FAQ later.

outputs: Checkout content pack: promise, bullets, and policies
End-to-end test notes and a prioritized fix list
wrap.tomorrowPreview: Tomorrow you will design your first workflow so delivery happens the same way each time and nothing falls through the cracks.
